Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story:
I glanced at my phone, the screen lighting up with a message from my partner: “Relatives will be here in two hours. Can you vacuum and tidy the living room before they arrive?” I looked around the salon, my hands still damp from rinsing out a client’s hair dye. The morning had been a blur of appointments, but I’d promised to help at home. I felt the weight of expectation settle on my shoulders—my partner counting on me to share the load, to make our home welcoming for family.

Just then, the bell above the salon door chimed. A woman stepped in, her eyes darting nervously from the reception desk to the row of chairs. She clutched her purse, hesitating. I knew that look—first-time jitters. My boss always said, “Make every client feel at home.” I was supposed to greet her warmly, offer tea, and ease her nerves.

But my mind was split. I could almost see the dust on the living room shelves, hear my partner’s voice in my head. I stood frozen, torn between the comfort I owed this anxious client and the support I owed my spouse, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in.
